Once their flag is full, they must then answer a question in the category of their opponents' choice to seal the win.

22883.name: PSL Guide to Wargaming
22883.description:
This introduction to miniature wargaming includes an introduction and articles by eight different authors on wargaming 10 different historical periods. At the end of each chapter, Quarrie presents rules for that particular period.

The historical periods covered include the following: Ancients, Medieval, Renaissance/17th century, 18th century, Napoleonic, Crimean war, American Civil/Franco-Prussian wars, Colonial warfare, World War I, and World War II.

22884.description:
Reiner Knizia gives us a new expansion for the classic Lord of the Rings board game. Each of the boards from the main game has a corresponding battlefield, and players maneuver heroes and villains on these battlefields to improve their position in the fully integrated main game.

From the ancient ruins of Weathertop to the conflict at the Black Gate of Mordor, the journey of the Fellowship of the Ring is marked with battle. The armies of Sauron are on the march, and unless the courage and faith of the Fellowship can hold, the Shadow will be victorious.

The new Battlefields expansion for Reiner Knizia's acclaimed Lord of the Rings board game focuses on the deadly combats that the Fellowship must survive on its quest to destroy the One Ring. Now in addition to guiding the Fellowship through its many perils, the players also help to hinder or defeat Sauron's powerful armies, because the farther enemies march on the battlefield board, the more destruction they cause and the closer Sauron comes to recovering the One Ring!

Will Aragorn arrive in time to defend against the Witch King at Weathertop? Will Boromir's courage hold against the savage Uruk-Hai? Will Gimli's axe be enough to withstand a horde of orcs at the Chamber of Mazarbul? Join the fight with the Lord of the Rings: Battlefields expansion.

Contents

3 double-sided battlefield boards
5 Fellowship pieces
30 Enemy pieces
20 trigger tiles
6 Feature cards
3 Gandalf cards





Expands:

Lord of the Rings
22884.name: Lord of the Rings: Battlefields
boardgamefamily: Lord of the Rings (Reiner Knizia's co-op game)

boardgamehonor: 2006 Deutscher Lernspielpreis "3 years and up" Nominee
2006 Deutscher Lernspielpreis "3 years and up" Winner
22885.description:
The most skillful "cheese-knocker", who lets her mouse hide the most often in the delicious cheese before that mouse is caught by the cat, receives for her successes many pieces of cheese (which act as victory points).

Ages 5-99
22885.name: Alles Käse

22886.name: Gefahr über Sunnydale
boardgamefamily: TV Series: 	Buffy the Vampire Slayer
22886.description: "Gefahr über Sunnydale" (Sunnydale in Danger) is an adventure game based on the television series "Buffy the Vampire Slayer". One player battles as the great master the other players who use 5 of 6 heroes (Buffy, Xander, Willow, Giles, Oz and Riley), each with his own special ability. The great master chooses secretly one of 4 scenarios, which determines amongst other things the boss monster (Master, Spike, Wilkins III or Adam). The game has 2 phases. Phase A is the investigation phase, where the heroes move through the town of Sunnydale to find 5 pieces of evidence about the boss monster while battling hordes of minor monsters. Battles are fought with rolling dice and comparing strength and stamina. When the heroes have found who the opponent is and where he lives, phase B - the confrontation phase- starts, which is played on the backside of the board and consists of one battle between the heroes and the boss monster and his surviving adjutants.

22887.name: The Honeybee Tree
22887.description: This game consists of several plastic pieces and a large six sided die with 6 different symbols. One must roll the die in order to add pieces to his/her tree and things must be added in order in the appropriate places. There are five different piece types: branch, leaf, blossom, butterfly, and bee. All have a symbol on the die. The sixth symbol on the die is a beehive that allows any piece that the roller desires to be placed on the tree. The winner is the first to successfully construct a tree.

boardgamehonor: 2006 Lucca Games Best Concept Art
2008 Årets Spill Best Party Game Nominee
2008 Kinderspielexperten "8-to-13-year-olds" Nominee
22889.description:
From the designer & publisher:

Pictureka! is a new kind of game, both in mechanic as in artwork. The mechanic is invigorating with its large square gaming tiles. The game board is composed of 3 by 3 game tiles, so the game board on which is played is a huge square of 63 cm x 63 cm. This is large enough for several players to be able to play the game at the same time. The game board is “alive”, it is not a static board as the tiles are flipped over, turned and moved. So it is not possible to memory map the board. The mechanic of an ever changing board makes it not only fun; also the challenge is kept into the game all the time.

A game turn
Players will have to throw a color dice at the beginning of their turn. According to the color thrown (3 possibilities) they must draw a mission card of the same color. There are 3 kinds of missions.

How to win the game?
Be the first one to have successfully accomplished 10 missions. Each successful mission gives 1 point, so be the first one to get 10 points.
The artwork is something not to be found in ‘standard’ games. The personal drawing style of the artist Eugene makes this a kind of playing artwork.

Components

9 game tiles
1 die (6-sided - standard d6)
1 color die (6-sided - 2 red, 2 green, 2 blue)
55 mission cards
1 sand timer (30 Seconds)
22889.name: Pictureka!

22890.name: In Other Words
22890.description:
Object: Be the first team to complete all categories: Movies, Books, Songs, and Saying & Quotations.

In a game with 3 or more teams, to complete a category a team must solve two clues in that category; if you are playing with only two teams, you must solve three clues per category. Answers have additional information in parentheses such as the author's or singer's name.

22891.name: The Earth Dinner
22891.description:
The Earth Dinner is an animated theme dinner party for all ages, connecting people to their food and the earth -- and each other.

The Earth Dinner uses cards to provoke discussion of our food, where it comes from, and how we experience it.

(Adapted from introduction in game rules.)

22892.name: Huckepack
22892.description:
A game similar to Pachisi (or Mensch-ärgere-dich-nicht) but with some difference. You can go on another pawn and the pawn downside must carry your pawn.

Big board, 47 * 47 cm and big wooden pawns.

First edition from 1970.
Also playable:
- Husch ins Körbchen!

Another edition from 1979.
There are two more versions also playable:
- Schlitzohr,
- Schwitzkasten

22893.name: Surf's Up! Hawaii
22893.description: The surfing game of Hawaii, hit the beach, catch a wave, keep track of expenses as you travel the beaches of Hawaii. It is an adventure of tall crashing waves and long surfboards.

22894.description:
Publisher's Description

There comes a time in every munchkin's career when he's taken on more than he can handle, bitten off more than he can chew, gotten in over his head. It's time for - the Narrow S Cape.

With 112 cards to enhance your Super Munchkin game, The Narrow S Cape is much more than just this season's favorite fashion accessory! It teems with new villains like the contemptible Cheese Wiz, Gothzilla (with earthquake-causing platform boot action!), and the Ratwoman. And lest you feel overwhelmed by villainy, this expansion also features new items, new Powers and a new Class: the Brain!

Wield the Slide Rule and Power Ring against Sister Blister! Tackle Tackyman with the Trampoline! Endure the Two-Hour Monolog because you were Raised By Armadillos! And flee from Shaenon K. Garrity's fearsome Foot and the unfortunate, mind-controlled Too Much Coffee Man!

Super Munchkin 2 - The Narrow S Cape... the ultimate expansion for the bestselling Munchkin series.


Other

Part of the Munchkin series
22894.name: Super Munchkin 2: The Narrow S Cape
boardgameexpansion: Munchkin Sparkly Good Fairy Shot Glass

22895.name: Baffle Box
22895.description:
The game contains a plastic board with 6x6 holes in it, 36 marbles, 6 colored pegs and 6 white pegs.

Players try to get rid of their marbles by placing them in the holes in the board. If a player thinks that a row is full of marbles he can challenge the move. The winner of the challenge gets rid of one of his marbles.

When a player has no marbles remaining the round ends.

22896.name: Hextravaganza
22896.description:
This game is based on my home town of Hexham, in the
north-east of England:

At the start of the game players get given a set "business cards" and write down the shop name on the card. the cards are placed back in the deck, the game commences. Players use three "shoppers" to get to the shops on their shopping list(moving 1,2 or 3 spaces in total, like 1 piece moves 1 square and anouther moves 2, in 1 go). If another player lands on your piece they get to move you anywhere on the board. once you have been to all your shops try to get all of your pieces to the stained glass window in the middle of the board.

boardgamehonor: 2007 Golden Geek Best 2-Player Board Game Nominee
22897.description:
From the publishers website:

In the near future, specially trained psychics called dream lords venture deep into the dreamscape. Here they explore a shifting landscape of ancient archetypes, modern terrors, and mismatched elements of the waking world. This is the shared unconsciousness of humanity, the boundless well of hopes and fears that makes us human. The reality they create in this timeless realm reverberates through the minds of dreamers everywhere. Some dream lords seek to protect it, others to dominate it, and others to destroy it.

The Dreamblade collectible miniatures game allows you to project your mind into the dreamscape and wage war against an endless sea of rivals. Draw upon psychic energies to create formidable creatures that you control in battle. Confront your opponents, destroy their creations and drive them from the dreamscape!

Current status : The game has been discontinued as of October 2007, no more new sets will be produced.

Released Sets:

Base Set - 96 miniatures
Baxar's War - 60 miniatures
Chrysotic Plague - 60 miniatures
Anvilborn - 60 miniatures
Night Fusion - 60 miniatures
22897.name: Dreamblade

22899.description: In this game each player has few cards in his hand. By discarding and getting new cards from other players, the players need to be the first to get 30 points in their hand. But, if they get more then 30 points, they lose. It's a light game that's very luck dependent.
22899.name: 30 points

22900.name: Trilli-Trilli
22900.description:
It is spring again. All nests contain already eggs. 16 cards are showing which bird should be on every nest. Only one card at a time is revealed. The player who, after having luck with the die rolling and some tactical dexterity, gets the right bird to the right nest, can keep the card.

The game box contains 16 nests, 16 cards, 4 birds and 1 die.

22901.name: Schnapp
22901.description:
Players each choose a color and then place wooden disks (6 of each color) face down to be mixed together. Players then take turns putting one face down disk on the long end of a see saw device. The player slaps the short end, sending the disk spinning into the air. All players try to figure out what color it is as it spins in the air and the player of that color should try to catch the disk before it lands. The first player to catch 4 disks wins. If you catch another player's disk or you block another player from catching their disk, they will still earn the disk.

Ages 4-99

22902.name: Queablo
22902.description:
This game combines a word game with mental arithmetic:
In each round, a magical number is determined with a dice. Open displayed cards show one consonant and one number at a time. Players try to build words with the open cards completed with some vocals. While searching for matching words, they always have to check the cross sum of the used numbers which must match the magical number.

The game comes together with 3 variants. More can be found on the official website.

22904.description: In the middle there is a board made of 9 cards 3X3. Each player will have always between 2-4 cards in there hand. Players put cards on the board, flipping cards, drawing cards and lying in order to put the card that will make 40 points. It’s a family game that requires memory and a bit of luck.
22904.name: 40 Barrels of Beer

22905.description:
The Phantom, Ruler of the Jungle, brings peace and safety to the natives. Called "The Ghost Who Walks", he is rarely seen except in time of trouble. Then, as a warning of his constant vigilance, he leaves the mark of his skull ring at the scene. Each player is The Phantom, trying to be the first to reach all of the trouble areas and leave a skull ring mark as a sign of protection.

A plastic skull ring is included.
22905.name: The Phantom, Ruler of the Jungle Game

22906.name: Transet
22906.description:
Transet is a chess variant played on a 5x5 grid using 5 pieces: rook, bishop, king, bishop and rook. The goal of the game is to reach the opposite side of the board with one of your pieces. The rook can only move one step straight forward, the bishop one step diagonally forward and the king combines the power of the rook and the bishop.

The game only has 5 rules. A small change in rule 1 or 5 (which determine begin & end conditions) makes that the game can be played with 1, 3, 4 or 5 players. The game is published in different versions, only changing color and artwork.

22907.description:
Five dragons race around a track. Players bet on three of the dragons. Play cards to move your dragons forward and hope that other players also want your dragons to win.

Illustrations by Marino Degano. Ages 14+. In the L-Series of games.
22907.name: Dragons' Derby

22908.name: Buck Rogers
22908.description:
This vintage game was a 3-in-1 package: Cosmic Rocket Wars, Search for the Secrets of Atlantis, and Siege of Gigantica. Each was for 2 to 4 players, allowing up to 12 players to be accomodated at once. There are three colorful 16x16" game boards, one for each game. The components also include 40 cards, with black and white illustrations, and 12 wooden playing pieces. Listed as being for ages 8 to adult.

Reportedly offered as a Cream of Wheat premium in addition to being available in stores.

22909.description:
This is an expansion for Axis & Allies. It contains revisions to the game rules to make it more realistic in areas such as aircraft range, income, retreats, making new units, etc. Introduces artillery rules, new rules for choosing combat losses, and advanced weapons development. To better match the history and politics of the era, the game also introduces air transports, airborne assaults, sub economic warfare, the Russian-Japanese Non-Aggression Pact, and more.

Expands:

Axis & Allies
22909.name: Axis & Allies Enhanced Realism Rules

22910.name: Naruto Collectible Card Game
22910.description: A new CCG based on the extremely popular anime show Naruto. The game has been released in Japan for a little while now and is making its American debut due to the success of the show. The use of Ninja, Jutsu, and themed Mission cards stay true to the mood of the anime.

22911.name: Brumm-Brumm
22911.description:
Two small cars are on the way home. The turn arrow determines in each case, whether they drive or must pull into the gas station, in order to fill up. Naturally, the traffic light must be respected, as in proper traffic.

This is a seizing and sliding game for the smallest children, from which nothing can be lost: The game pieces are firmly connected to the wooden game board.

AGES 2 YEARS AND UP

boardgamehonor: 2006 Årets Spill Best Children's Game Nominee
22912.name: Speedybag
22912.description:
Fast-paced and exciting action game for all ages! As a card is turned on the table, all players reach inside their bags and try to find the object pictured in the card, just by feeling with their fingers. If you are the first to find the correct object, you get the card. The winner is the player who has the most cards at the end of the game!

2006 Nominert til Årets Barnespill - Nominated for Children's Game of the Year, Norway

22913.name: Nautilus
boardgameversion: PERI Compact Games Jewel Case Edition
22913.description: The game consists of a spiral recessed track, 32 small containers (8 in each of 4 colors) and 16 chips. The chips are put in half the containers (four per color) and the containers are mixed together so that the locations of the chips are hidden. The containers are placed in the spiral and players take turns rearranging the containers. When players move pieces of their own color (or have permission from the owning player) they shake them and listen for the chips. When four pieces of a color are in a row in the spiral, the player collects the chips contained within. The first player to find all of his chips wins. (The complete rules contain a number of additional details.)

22914.name: Rocket Race
22914.description: An innovative space game with a real flying rocket! The astronauts are trying to get home from the alien planet but the air from the ground keeps blowing them off the path – the players use the pump to control the air streams. The first one to reach the rocket safely gets to fly home in it!

22915.description: Squeak your way to victory! This funny clown has a squeaky nose and chunky buttons that need to be placed in the correct ”button holes”. Spin the big spinner and rush to find the correct shaped button in front of you. The first player to fit his/her button in the correct hole and squeak the clown’s nose wins the round.
22915.name: Clown Around

22916.description:
From the publisher:

So far the Soviet, German, British and Italian soldiers in the Sergeants! On the Eastern Front game system have had it pretty much to themselves. Oh, there’s a deadly assortment of mortars, flamethrowers and shaped-charge weapons and that nasty German infantry gun, but it has always been the shoulder weapons that settled the issue and decided the outcome of a scenario. SERGEANTS! – Expansion adds U. S. Army and French soldiers to that reliable mix.
22916.name: Sergeants! Expansion

22917.name: Flotter Falter
22917.description: A memory game for children in which matching butterfly wings are added to bodies.

22918.name: Vinspillet
22918.description: The Idea with "Vinspillet" is that the players in a fun and entertaining way get knowledge about French wine. Players role a die and move on a map of France. The players can buy chateaus when landing on one, if you land on another players chateau you have to pay him/her money buying a cask of wine. Players may trade with each other during the game. At some spots you have to pick up a special event card and do as the card tells you. If you land on a a spot with a question mark you get a question form the pile of question marked cards. If your answer is right you win a number of casks equal to a die roll. The game ends when all chateaus are sold. The winner is the one who has the most capital when having counted money and the value of his/her properties.

22919.name: Love Game
22919.description:
This game contains four pieces representing men and four pieces representing women. Either up to four men chase one ideal woman in hopes of getting dates or four women chase one ideal man. Players simultaneously set their love-o-meters to indicate movement for either themselves or (by paying a gift chip) the ideal member of the appropriate sex. Dates lead to heart chips, which can be lost for various reasons. Landing on the spot with another figure, a die is rolled for a random consequence (losing a turn, losing a heart chip, gaining a heart chip). When all heart chips are distributed, the player with the most wins.

Illustrations by Mordillo. Ages 14+. L-Series of games.

22920.description:
A simple children's race game which takes place on a colorful map of the northeast U.S. The board and its spaces are illustrated with characters from the Dick Tracy comic strip.

Components include a game board, four markers, and spinner. Rules are printed inside the box lid.
22920.name: Dick Tracy Detective Game

22921.name: 007 Underwater Battle from Thunderball
22921.description:
A rare James Bond themed board game based on the underwater battle sequence from the movie Thunderball - Largo v. James Bond!

The game features some attention getting components. These include colorful plastic scuba swimmer figures on clear plastic pedestals with metal bases. There are also similarly mounted shark figures. The battle takes place on a glossy seascape mapboard. Rules are printed inside the lid.

22922.name: Vanessa Kay's Pin Up Mania
22922.description:
From the publisher:
Your favorite Juggy from TV's Man Show!

From the trampoline of TV's Man Show direct to your gaming table, it's our exciting new card game featuring Vanessa Kay.

Race to be the first to complete a Pin Up of Vanessa and win the game. Collect the cards you need to win or block your opponent's play in this fast paced game.


Two to four players



Thirty to forty minute playing time



Be the first to complete a Pin Up of Vanessa and win!

22923.name: Die Augen der Kali
22923.description: Players take turns moving a figure towards the goddess Kali, collecting gems as they move. They draw cards one at a time and move as many spots as indicated on the cards and get corresponding gems. If they quit before drawing a bad card, then they keep the gems. Otherwise the gems are lost in addition to 1/4 of the player's hoard. Play continues until the figure reaches Kali or the second Kali-waking card is drawn (the first one causes the drawing player to lose half of his gems).

boardgameimplementation: Hand-Off: The Card Football Board Game
22924.description:
Card Football is a playing card-based board game which follows the basic rules of American football. Players battle to win the down by playing the strongest hand.

Game play combines elements of classic playing card games to simulate the action on the field. Players must decide how best to play their cards. For instance, cards can be played individually, in pairs, two pair, three-of-a-kind, or five-card poker-style 'Power Hands'. Much like a football coach deciding what play to call, or the quarterback choosing his best option, players must decide whether to play strong card(s) immediately, or to hold back in hopes of using it to put together a stronger hand.

Other elements of Card Football include team and player chips, game board, a score board, a referee/yard marker and dice that are used for fumble, field goal and injury situations.

Card Football allows for one, two, three and four-player modes. The single-player game mode is set up so that an individual can take on 'the system' and pick up the basics of the game before challenging friends in an all-out gridiron battle. In addition, the learning curve with Card Football is remarkably low. Typically, the game is learned in two to five minutes, or after a few series of downs.

If it happens on the field, you'll find it in Card Football. From field goals, punts and extra points, to fumbles, interceptions and last-second heroics, you get it all in four quarters of Card Football action.
22924.name: Card Football: Premiere Edition

22925.name: VeggieTales Puzzler
22925.description:
From the Publisher:

"It's exciting! It's Baffling! It's VeggieTales Puzzler, the most amazing game you've ever played! Find 4 cards on the playing grid that form a picture. Shout "PUZZLE" then take the cards off the grid and flip the timer over. Correctly arrange the cards to form a picture before time runs out... it's that simple!"

22926.name: Take a Hike!
22926.description:
From the box:

Kids take a hike through the forest in a race to fill their backpacks and reach Camp Fun. Players choose which animals they want to collect, then move around the board collecting those animals. The animals stick to the backpacks, then peel off so that they can be used over and over again. Take-a-Hike! is simple enough so that 4 year olds, can quickly learn to play, but interesting enough to hold older kids' attention, too.

This was designed by a five year old, Derek Nelson, the winner of the 1994 National Young Game Inventors contest.

22927.description:
This expansion for Axis & Allies is designed to add realism, historical accuracy, strategy enhancement, and play balance to the base game. New elements added to the game include increased production, destroyer escorts, sub patrols, anti-sub patrols, destroyers, cruisers, capital warships, depth charge attacks, wolf packs, air search missions, and more.

Expands:

Axis & Allies
22927.name: World War II The Expansion

22928.name: Win, Lose or Draw Junior
22928.description:
From back of box:
"This simpler Junior version of Win, Lose or Draw is designed for children ages 8 to 11!
To play, kids pick a card, select a word and call out its category -- People, Places or Things! The sketching starts! The guessing begins! It's a race against time.
Correct guesses reward both the Sketcher and the Guesser with chips. Collect enough chips and then guess correctly once more to win!"

22929.description:
This is Gamers Paradise's third expansion for Axis & Allies and focuses on the Pacific Theater, adding rules to make the conflict in the Pacific more realistic and interesting. Includes rules for recreating the bombing of Tokyo by the Doolittle Raid through the historical events that led up to the Battle of Midway in June of 1942. This expansion contains a large 30" x 50" full color heavy duty polypropylene map, the "Midway Scenario" rulebook, and 40 color counters.

Expands:

Axis & Allies
22929.name: World War II Expansion 3: The Battle of Midway

22930.name: Räubersprung
22930.description: Players each get three figures in different colors. They move their figures along like-colored lines to collect treasure bags, to steal the bags from other players and to change the amount of treasure that will win the game.

22931.name: Brillance
22931.description:
You have to supply the shops of a medieval town (Brillance).
The one who can supply the most shops before sunrise (10 turns) is the winner.
The problem is that the streets are very narrow, so they get blocked of by the other players. Each round you receive an obstaclecard, with which you can obstruct your compagnions' routes. Give their carts a broken wheel, put a drunken dwarf in their way, make them crash with other players, call the guards on them etc. Obstructing your fellowplayers is one of the main mechanisms of the game and also what makes this game so fun.

Brillance combines strategy with a bit of screw-your-neighbor.

22932.name: 10-Die Poker
22932.description:
Each player gets a set of 10 dice; 5 of one color, and 5 of another. Each person rolls his dice in pairs, one of each color, and after rolling all 5 pairs he determines which set of 5 dice of the same color makes a better poker hand.

Most of the standard rules of draw poker apply, including betting. The key here is that each pair of dice is always rolled together.

For example, if you have 3 of a Kind with your blue dice, and a Pair with your red dice, you might choose to roll two sets of dice (i.e., a blue die and a red one, twice, but ALWAYS rolling the same two dice of each set together throughout the game), hoping for a 4 or 5 of a Kind. Continuing the example, you might not add to your 3 of a Kind with the blue dice, but maybe you'll pick up a Full House with the red. No problem -- now you're betting on a Full House. You can switch back and forth on the hand you're rolling on (blue dice or red), but you must always keep the individual pairs of dice together.

22933.description:
This game uses three dice to simulate a soccer match.
Two dice have black letters and sides that say ‘Defense’, ‘Mid-field Play’ and ‘Attack’ (2 of each). The third die has blue letters and the sides say ‘Mid-field’, ‘Swift Change’, ‘Penalty’, ‘Corner’, ‘Free Kick’ and ‘Goal’.
The dice with black letters relate to the pitch and determine if the attacker may take a shot at goal or not. The die with blue letters is used to take a shot at goal.
Players take turns rolling the dice and the first player to score 3 goals wins.
22933.name: Globall

22934.name: Kosherland
22934.description:
Kosherland is a game designed for very young Jewish children that not only teaches them about colors, learning and following rules, and communication, but also important parts of their religion. The game plays just like the classic Candy Land, with the only real differences being that it has a Kosher food theme and a built-in spinner. Special events on some spaces allow the player to move to different spaces.

As with Candy Land, the first player to reach the end of the board wins.

22935.name: Temporal Trade
22935.description: In Temporal Trade, with one of eight scenario's to choose from, the game is begun in the past time frame and players may elect to purchase businesses and improve upon their business with the purchase of business facilities or stores in the past. However when one player lands upon a "Pier" space and meets the conditions required on the pier space, the player may enter in to a path of contiguous spaces leading into the interior of the game board which intersect at a central space entitled the "Temporal Time Ship Space" or time portal wherein the entire game, if that player so chooses, is transported into the future and all costs and expenses automatically change for all players. Of course, a second player, upon arriving at the "Temporal Trade Time Ship Space", may elect to transport the game values back into the past phase tense. The goal is to avoid bankruptcy where in you would be eliminated from the game, but to become the richest or last player who has accumulated the greatest wealth, including the value of businesses, property, and cash on hand over the game playing period.

22937.name: How to Host a Murder: An Affair to Dismember
22937.description: A storm rages outside and the Halloween midnight buffet at the Castle Von Morgue is about to commence. Your host Neville Aster-Night is nowhere to be seen. As you all gather in the mourning room, the head servant apprises everyone of her master's murder. As you assume the role of one of these ghoulish characters and solve the mystery, you and your seven dinner guests will enjoy hours of suspense and intrigue. All you need is a sense of humor and a light-hearted approach toward deceit, larceny, sex and murder.

22938.description:
In Justinian the players try to win the favor of Emperor Justinian. To further their aims and to strengthen their position at court, they bribe influential persons at Justinian´s court.
These bribes are represented by four different colors in the game: At the end of each game turn one color is scored. The players get victory points if their court followers have increased their clout at court. However, only three of the four colors in Justinian are scored!

Game Microbadges: (Buy One)

Designer Leo Colovini Microbadges: (Buy One)
22938.name: Justinian
boardgamepodcastepisode: PGGK 048: Justinian

22939.description: Heroes and villains of Marvel Comics like Hulk, Wolverine and Magneto fight in an arena. Each player choses a team of two characters - each one gets a pair of unique special powers cards. The movement and the outcome of the battles are decided by the throw of special dice. Two places of the board restore the life points or the special powers of the characters. The first player to knock out all his opponents wins.
22939.name: Marvel Heroes Jogo

22940.name: All is lost save Honour
22940.description:
from Europa Simulazioni website:

“All is lost save Honour” is a game about the campaigns fought during the Italian Wars (1494-1530), mainly between the Hapsburgs (the Empire) and the Valois (the French kingdom). The first volume is devoted to campaigns between Agnadello (1509) and Pavia (1525)

All began after reading Taylor’s “The Art of War in Italy 1494-1529”, London, 1920. Soon that period looked extremely interesting to us and nearly neglected by the wargame community.
Our intent was to generate any interest, among “aficionados” and historians, about that ancient era, when the first applications of modern strategy in the art of war took place.

This is the time of charges of cavalrymen with the finest gliding armors; of the first use of fire arms and artillery (with some effect); sieges, mercenary troops, treachery, pillaging and all that “chrome” that may enlighten a wargame.

Those campaigns were led to bring to “the battle”, which was often decisive, we decided to bring in a detailed sequence of the main battle (said “Major Battle”). So in the game, there are three kinds of battle: Major Battle, Skirmish and Siege with the Major Battle involving different tactics played by each side.

The map represents Lombardy in the XVIth century and the neighbors states. The sources for the maps were new books and old manuscripts and maps, among which a manuscript dated 1520 (!), regarding the state of the roads in the area between Lodi and Piacenza.
Many books have been written about this subject and I think we have read the most important ones.

We had to make a selection of all those campaigns fought in Italy during the Italian Wars. The five campaigns we have included are:
- Agnadello 1509, Venice defends its Republic against the foes.
- Novara 1513, the Swiss against the French army. The last triumph of the Swiss.
- Marignano 1515, François I grabs the Duchy of Milan from the Swiss
- Bicocca 1522, the French lose the Duchy of Milan
- Pavia 1525, François I loses the largest battle and Milan to the Empire

Game Highlights:

new game system, operational-level, devoted to warfare in the XVIth century campaigns
highly interactive sequence of play, focused on maneuver and careful planning
various forms of combat: Major Battles, Skirmishes, Sieges
set of Exclusive Rules and specific rules and events for each campaign
a 22" x 34" fine-art map , reproducing a part of XVIth northern Italy, based on an accurate study of ancient maps and sources
gorgeous iconic counters representing all the main Capitani who fought there and the different combat units
detailed (as it is possible) order of battle, with combat units differentiated by strength, maximum movement, quality and reliability
very low counter density and limited play time

22941.name: Mystical Empire CCG
22941.description:
Mystical Empire is an Action-Based game, so everything that takes place during the game requires the use of an Action by either a Character or a Creature or a combination of several.

With your Character’s Actions, you may Hire Creatures, Play Items & Structures, or (if able) cast Spells & Effects. Your Character may also Attack once per turn, if you choose, and may save an Action to Defend against Attacks made during your Opponent’s turn.

With your Creature’s Actions, you may Attack your Opponent’s Character or Built Structure(s), Defend against Attacks made by your Opponent’s Character & Creatures, use Special Abilities (which will be written on each card), or (if able) cast Spells & Effects.

Your ultimate goal is to destroy your Opponent’s Character. Once this has been achieved, you win the game.

22942.description: A game detailing Alexander's brilliant siege of Tyre in 332 B.C., using the old-school grid movement system. Includes all relevant land, naval, and siege units, as well as pieces to build Alexander's mole out to the city.
22942.name: Alexander's Triumph

22943.name: Royal
22943.description: This is a boardgame that uses a regular deck of cards. Players have pieces representative of the face cards in the deck. Spot on the board are blank or marked with suits. Pieces are moved by use of cards (double value with suit matching the player). Players can send others' pieces back to their start positions, but not if the pieces are sitting on squares of their own suit.

22944.name: Bao Arabica
22944.description: Bao Arabica is a modern Mancala game, although for marketing reasons it got an exotic name. The game can be played by 2, 3 or even 4 players, which is rather unusual for Mancala. Moves can be made in either direction, clockwise or counterclockwise. In the two-person variant, each player controls two separate camps, one on each side of the board. The inventor is a co-owner of HiKu games.

22945.name: Presidents Rummy
22945.description:
Packed with information, Presidents Rummy teaches children about US Presidents and the eras in which they served. A rummy game is supplemented by numerous variations.

Game includes 50 playing cards (includes 2 blank cards for future Presidents which is handy as the last one is Bill Clinton), 2 directions cards, and 2 additional information cards

22946.name: Stadsspel
22946.description:
A series of Monopoly clones about various Swedish cities. Each game has an identical set of rules and components, except for the game board, which is adapted to the city in question.

As in Monopoly, the game is about moving around a board, buying property, drawing cards and paying rent. The object of the game is to eliminate all other players by forcing them into bankruptcy. The players can also agree upon an alternative victory condition before the game begins; the player who owns at least half of all properties is declared the winner.

The game board is covered with advertising. The properties you buy are actually real Swedish companies who reside in the city the game is about.

The big difference from the original Monopoly is the possibility to buy stock. There are five kinds of stock (coffee, coal, iron, oil and gold) with different odds and payout.

boardgamehonor: 2008 As d'Or - Jeu de l'Année Nominee
22947.description:
From a minimal board made up of four hexagonal flagstones, the players must extend their territory by gaining new flagstones. For that, they each use eight pawns and try to make leave the unfavourable pawns the board in order to imprison them to later release them. Exxit deploys a simple and original mechanism: the distribution, which creates astonishingly complex tactical and strategic situations.

A winner of the 2004 Concours International de Créateurs de Jeux de Société.

Online Play


Boardspace.net (real-time, AI option)
Boîte à jeux (turn-based)
22947.name: Exxit

boardgamehonor: 2006 Origins Awards Non-Collectable Card Game or Expansion of the Year Winner
22948.description:
Publisher's Description

The Munchkins are now spies... eliminating the opposition, playing with self-destructing gadgets, and changing loyalties even faster than they change hats.

Be a Playboy, Tourist, or Assassin. Report to the Americans, Russians, British, or Chinese (it'll change!). Wield gadgets from the subtle Cigarette Dart Gun to the amazingly unsubtle Bazooka with Incendiary Ammo. Eliminate foes, from the pathetic Defective Defector, through the Interro-Gator and the Not So Secret Police, up to the mighty Super Spy himself. And (all together now)... 'Take Their Stuff!'

You can play Munchkin Impossible by itself, or combine it with any number of other Munchkin games for more shameless silliness.


Other

Part of the Munchkin series.

Munchkin is a satirical card game based on the clichés and oddities of Dungeons and Dragons and other role-playing games. Each player starts at level 1 and the winner is the first player to reach level 10. Players can acquire familiar D&D style character classes during the game which determine to some extent the cards they can play.

There are two types of cards - treasure and encounters. Each turn the current players 'kicks down the door' - drawing an encounter card from the deck. Usually this will involve battling a monster. Monsters have their own levels and players must try and overcome it using the levels, weapons and powers they have acquired during the game or run away. Other players can chose to help the player or hinder by adding extra monsters to the encounter. Defeating a monster will usually result in drawing treasure cards and acquiring levels. Being defeated by a monster results in "bad stuff" which usually involves losing levels and treasure.
22948.name: Munchkin Impossible
boardgameexpansion: Munchkin Sparkly Good Fairy Shot Glass

22949.name: D-Code
22949.description: One player thinks of a word and places letter-tiles face-down on the table. The other player must guess the word as tiles are revealed.

22950.name: Play Nine
22950.description:
Play Nine is the new card game of golf designed for 2 - 6 players, ages 8 to adult. The object is to shoot the lowest score. After nine holes, the lowest score wins. Card values range from -5 (hole-in-one) to 12 (out of bounds). Golfers and non-golfers alike enjoy Play Nine. The combination of strategy and luck-of-the-draw keeps the fun and challenge alive down to the last hole. Play Nine, the card game of golf, is easy to learn and fun to play so - Let's Play Nine!

From publisher-

22951.name: NATO Vs. Warsaw Pact: 1989
22951.description: This is a 'what-if' variant on Axis & Allies set in 1989 during the outbreak of a global conflict between NATO and the Warsaw Pact countries. Player nations include the USSR and China on one side and the USA and NATO on the other, with plenty of neutral countries which may join one side or the other during the course of the game. Maps, charts, and rules are all provided but you must provide your own playing pieces.

22952.description:
This is Gamers Paradise's second expansion for Axis & Allies and is meant to be played both with the original game by Milton Bradley, and the first expansion set by Gamers Paradise. The Pacific Ocean has been enlarged and territory values have been increased to make the Pacific Theater of Operations more interesting and realistic. This expansion comes with a rulebook and 80 diecut, full color counters for: Artillery, Air Transports, Paratroopers, Carrier-based Aircraft (Zeros and Hellcats), Truck Troop Carriers, German SS Units, British Commando Units, U.S. Marines, Japanese Defensive Fortifications (Pillboxes), and Fighters Unavailable for Flight Duty.

Expands:

Axis & Allies
22952.name: World War II Expansion 2

22953.name: Soviet System
22953.description:
This game (in French) was published in 1988 by Milton Bradley France. No information suggests it has been published in another country or language.

The game is a combination of roll-and-move and answering questions. The goal is to become the new Secretary General of the USSR Communist Party.

22954.name: Flight Path
22954.description:
Billed as "the exciting flying race", this game presents a race competition between up to six glider pilots.

From the box: "Your objective, having been launched to 10,000 feet in your glider, is to race across the countryside avoiding all manner of obstacles, hoping not to crash land before you get to the finish."

"Stretching your flying skills to the limit as your competitors place tactical problems in your path, you are forced to search the sky for those much needed thermals to gain valuable height in order to clear the mountain tops and reach the final winning runway."

22955.name: Wild West War Pigs
22955.description: The newest in the War PIGs (Plastic Infantry Guys) series, Wild West War PIGs pits plastic Cowboys and Injuns against each other.

22956.name: Death by Dice
22956.description: Each player controls a character with six different traits, each represented by a different kind of dice (d6, d8, d4). Players choose which traits they wish to attack in and the players roll dice for the attack. Twisted little characters duke it out with dice. A fast-paced, strategy dice game played head to head using a combination of character attributes, special abilities, and lots of dice. (From the website) There are two editions to choose from: Nursery Wars - the gang from the Mother Goose tales gone horribly wrong, includes Ma Goose, Bo Peep, the Mice and One Angry Sheep; and the Gangland Edition, featuring 20s style mobsters such as Knuckles, Malice, and The Shadow. A single game can be played in five minutes, but has a Boss/Minion variation for those who want more dice and strategy options. Each set of Death by Dice includes two character boards and rules. 10 sets in all, dice not included.

22958.name: Clout: Marvel
22958.description:
An expansion to Clout Fantasy set in the Marvel Universe.

As of early 2007, this game's release is on indefinite hold.

The Clout range seems to have been discontinued.

22960.name: Don't Crack
22960.description: Don't Crack is the game where you are not allowed to laugh smile, smirk, grin, or giggle however it is almost impossible. Imagine if you pick up a card and it says. " Coffee is a natural laxative for me." You had to read it out loud without proofreading. Would that make you laugh? possibly. What if you had to get down on one knee and grab the persons hand to your left and confess your undying love for them. Would that make you laugh? Probably. If anyone laughs during game play they must move back spaces. Two categories are used, " Feel The Part" the acting out a silly situation category and "say It Out Loud" where you just pick up and read it. A game of non stop laughter.

22961.name: Pick -a- Penguin
22961.description: Each player chooses to be one of four colored penguins at the South Pole: Yellow, Green, Red or Blue. There are four penguins of each color. All sixteen penguins start out in the center of a rotating iceberg, all mixed up. The penguins are trying to get back to their home igloo. On a player's turn, he rolls the large picture/number die, which will indicate how many penguins may be picked from the iceberg. The player then keeps all of his or her color penguins and returns the other penguins to the iceberg. The player may also roll the die to indicate that the iceberg should be rotated, thus mixing up the memorized order. The first player to bring all of his penguins back home is the winner!

22962.name: Patriot Act: The Home Version
22962.description:
Board and mechanics are based on Monopoly.

According to the publisher's website;

PATRIOT ACT: The Home Version, is a game inspired by the historic abuse of governmental powers of the same name. Many of the hypothetical situations in the game are based on real-life events. Either as a game to be played or as a statement to be read, Patriot Act: The Home Version educates the user to the current erosion of our civil rights by the government while claiming to be protecting our freedoms. John Ashcroft may no longer be Attorney General, but his legacy lives on in the anti-freedom legislation that this game is a tribute to.

The game is free and can be downloaded here: http://www.graphix4change.com/portfolio_PA_game.html

22963.name: Scuba-Opoly
boardgamepublisher: Late for the Sky Production Company
boardgameversion: Late for the Sky Production Company edition
22963.description: This is the original version of Scuba-Opoly. Play one of your favorite board games with a diving twist. Players collect research dives, trade them for data collection centers, go on treasure hunts and become DAN oxygen instructors.

22964.name: Wheel of Fortune Game Junior Edition
22964.description:
From back of box:
"Now younger players can enjoy all the fun and excitement of the popular TV game show anytime, any place in this fast-action home version developed especially for players age 7 to 12!

In Wheel of Fortune Junior Edition, you and your opponents compete to be the first player to solve the phrase hidden on the Puzzle Board -- a famous expression, title, person or thing. Spin the Wheel and uncover letters to earn money.

If you can avoid going 'Bankrupt' and complete the phrase, you win the round!

After four rounds, the player with the most cash wins the game!"

22965.name: Art Shark
22965.description:
Art Shark by Birdcage Press:

You need to be tricky as you bid for artwork, trying to make a fortune. You switch real artworks for fakes, fooling others into believing which is which. Outbid the other players at auction for the real ones, and make them bid higher on the fakes...

... and while playing, learn about 64 real art masterpieces!

In this set, there are 64 art cards, 54 chance cards, 2 dice. Ages 7 to adult.

22966.name: Double Trouble
22966.description:
A card game for 2 – 4 players with 60 cards.
The cards have 3 parts: below, in the middle and at the top of the cards.
In every part there is a colored symbol (yellow triangle, violet star, green circle, blue square).
Every card has a number.

At the beginning there are 4 cards on the table.
You have to place one of your cards aside of one of these 4 cards, so that 2 parts are in the same colors. Then the next player.

22967.name: American Art Ditto
22967.description:
American Art Ditto by Birdcage Press...

This is a memory card game about American artists. Match up pairs of art tiles showing works from the greatest American artists. Collect winnings on 8 art collecting cards that show the beauty and grandeur of life in America -- in the city, on the farm, and in the great outdoors.

48 memory cards and 8 art collecting cards that show art details on one side and full paintings on the other. Ages 4 and up.

22970.description:
Great Art Close Up...

Discover art of the great museums of the world as you play 5 fun card games, including "Memory," "Old Maid," and 2 new matching games for children of different ages. Turn your next visit to the art museum into a treasure hunt with each Close Up deck.

National Gallery of Art Closeup Deck...

Play matching games with this deck of 48 cards featuring masterpieces from the National Gallery. Ages 5 to adult.
22970.name: Great Art Close up: National Gallery of Art

22971.description:
Great Art Close Up...

Discover art of the great museums of the world as you play 5 fun card games, including "Memory," "Old Maid," and 2 new matching games for children of different ages. Turn your next visit to the art museum into a treasure hunt with each Close Up deck.

Getty Museum closeup...

Look closely to match close up details to the paintings they come from with this deck of 48 playing cards. Ages 5 to adult.
22971.name: Great Art Close up: The  J. Paul Getty Museum

22972.name: Pixelator
22972.description:
Kid Galaxy, best known for its remote control toys, enters the board game category with the Pixelator, a futuristic strategy board game with an electrobotic module that has a mind of its own.

The Kid Galaxy web site describes Pixelator as "a fascinating new strategy game" that "incorporates a unique, patented 'color recognition' technology."

More from the web site:
"Drive the Pixelator into your opponents home base to win. Play specially colored cards to maneuver Pixelator. The Pixelator magical all-knowing eye 'sees' the color and moves accordingly."

Pixelator is for 2 players or teams, ages 6 and up.

22973.name: Controversy!
22973.description:
(From the web site)

Think you know where your friends stand? You may be surprised. Everyone has an opinion, so here’s your chance to show off yours – pro, con, or “what if?”

Tackle tough issues of the day, like whether men are responsible for putting the toilet seat down, science vs. religion, and Seinfeld vs. Friends.

Tell it like it is – or how you’d like it to be. Air your views and change minds – maybe even your own.

WHO KNEW BEING RIGHT COULD BE SO MUCH FUN?? (tm)

Teens & Adults. 3 or more players.

22974.description:
Great Art Close Up...

Discover art of the great museums of the world as you play 5 fun card games, including "Memory," "Old Maid," and 2 new matching games for children of different ages. Turn your next visit to the art museum into a treasure hunt with each Close Up deck.

Moma Closeup deck

Play 5 different games with this deck of 48 museum-quality playing cards featuring great modern artists. Ages 5 to adult.
22974.name: Great Art Close up: The Museum of Modern Art

22975.description:
(from the web site)

WATCH OUT FOR T-REX! Discover the world of dinosaurs as you play three favorite card games: "Old Maid," "Go Fish," and "Concentration."

Discover:

- Which flesh-eating dinosaur was even bigger than T-Rex?
- Which dinosaurs had feathers but could not fly?
- Who was a "missing link" between dinosaurs and birds?

Learn a little French as you play different card games. The cards have dinosaur descriptions in both English and French. They also give each dinosaur's Latin name and how to pronounce it, and show you how big each dinosaur was.

47 playing cards and a dinosaur guide come in a fun tin box. Ages 5 and up.
22975.name: Old Dinosaur

22976.name: Art Ditto
22976.description:
Art Ditto from Birdcage Press...

In Art Ditto, you will to play memory games with great works of art, as you collect art collecting cards. Playing the game enables you to learn how different artists depict birds, boats, cats, flowers, horses, and more. Players will also learn words in four languages as they have fun with great art.

The game contains 48 memory tiles, 8 art collecting cards, and instructions in English, French, Spanish and German. Ages 4 and up.

22977.name: Renaissance Go Fish for Art
22977.description:
(from the web site)

Go Fish for Great Art!

Learn about great art as you play "Go Fish" and "Concentration" card games. Use strategy and memory to collect all the works of art by each artist. You don't need to know about art to win the game and you learn a lot as you play.

All 3 Go Fish for Art games are winners of a Parents' Choice Gold Medal.

Renaissance Go Fish for Art:

A deck of 30 museum-quality playing cards and a guide to the artists. Ages 7 to adult.

22978.description:
(from the web site)

Go Fish for Great Art!

Learn about great art as you play "Go Fish" and "Concentration" card games. Use strategy and memory to collect all the works of art by each artist. You don't need to know about art to win the game and you learn a lot as you play.

All 3 Go Fish for Art games are winners of a Parents' Choice Gold Medal.

Van Gogh & Friends Go Fish for Art:

A deck of 36 museum-quality playing cards and a guide to the artists. Ages 7 to adult.
22978.name: Van Gogh & Friends Go Fish for Art

22979.name: Impressionist Go Fish for Art
22979.description:
(from the web site)

Go Fish for Great Art!

Learn about great art as you play "Go Fish" and "Concentration" card games. Use strategy and memory to collect all the works of art by each artist. You don't need to know about art to win the game and you learn a lot as you play.

All 3 Go Fish for Art games are winners of a Parents' Choice Gold Medal.

Impressionist Go Fish for Art:

A deck of 32 museum-quality playing cards and a guide to the artists. Ages 7 to adult.

22980.name: Jeff Foxworthy's You Might Be a Redneck if... Game
boardgamepodcastepisode: Jeff Foxworthy’s You Might Be a Redneck If… Game
22980.description:
from the publisher Patch Products

Patch Products was recently granted the rights to produce The You Might be a Redneck If... Game. Everyone's heard of Jeff Foxworthy and his hilarious Redneck jokes. Now Patch Products brings his humor to the board game shelves.

You're a redneck. Start in your trailer and go through town, collecting "redneck" things like a bag o' jerky and a hound dog to bring back home. If you're the first redneck to collect everything and return to your trailer, you win.

On each turn you pick from three choices that correctly complete one of Jeff Foxworthy’s redneck jokes.

Sample Questions:

You might be a Redneck if... you wash your car more often than you wash your _____.
1. hair
2. kids
3. clothes

You might be a Redneck if... your mother doesn't put on _____ to go grocery shopping.
1. makeup
2. shoes
3. a bra

Dumb luck plays a role, too. If you land on a Dumb Luck spot, you must draw a card and may be required to do any of 30 different things, such as give up one of your treasures, or perform a Redneck stunt like hog-calling. A flip of the Redneck coin each time you encounter Dumb Luck decides if you will be the recipient of the Dumb Luck, or if you must force it upon one of your fellow Rednecks.

Jeff Foxworthy's You Might Be a Redneck If... Game is for 2 to 4 players ages 16 and up. (Answers to the clues: kids, shoes.)

Foxworthy is the largest selling comedy-recording artist in history, a multiple Grammy Award nominee and best selling author of 13 books. He starred in The Blue Collar Comedy Tour movie and the follow-up DVD, The Blue Collar Comedy Tour Rides Again. He also stars in and executive produces the WB hit television show "Blue Collar TV" and hosts a weekly country countdown radio show, The Foxworthy Countdown.

22981.name: American Idol All-Star Challenge DVD Game
22981.description:
from the web site

Experience all the excitement of American Idol as you journey from Auditions, to Hollywood and onward to the Finals round of competition. With real television clips from the first four seasons, plus show questions and performance challenges, American Idol – All Star Challenge will transform your living room into the ultimate TV talent showdown. Test your Idol knowledge as you relive all the trials and tribulations, the victories and the heartbreaks that have made American Idol one of the hottest shows on television today.

22982.name: Moby Dick: Das Spiel vom weißen Wal
22982.description:
(the german subtitle means: The game of the white whale)

An early oddity in the Ravensburger program: The game consists of an elevated round course with an underlying rotating cardboard disk - on their turn the players rotate the disk. Whenever a whale symbol appears, a small plastic whale miniature is put on the course.
The players now try to catch the whale with their ships (= reach the whale miniature), before it dives again (a hole in the rotating disk lets the miniature disappear into the game box).
The rotating disk also constantly changes the values for different whaling goods at a stock exchange. The player selling his cargo for the highest price wins.
Sometimes a white (plastic) whale appears which cannot be caught, but the player "wounding" Moby Dick gets a gold doubloon worth 200 $.

22983.name: Vis Magica
22983.description:
From the publisher's website

Rules for Fantasy Wargaming!

Fantasy wargaming system based on the popular Vis Bellica rules for Ancient & Medieval wargaming.

Figures based as chunky elements that correctly represent ground scale. Easy to move round the table and look good.

An average game consists of about 120 figures a side, and takes about 2½-3 hours of play to resolve.

A combat system that doesn’t involve complicated book-keeping or rolling more than two or three dice at a time.

A command structure where figures are grouped as regular ‘brigades’ or irregular ‘contingents’ that report to officers that report to more senior officers.

A command system where officers could, on a parade ground, successfully issue a limited set of orders to the figures under their command, but this ability breaks down rapidly as the 'fog of war' descends during a battle.
Hidden movement possible without the need for a referee.

An army list philosophy that allows you to use any figures from any manufacturer: to use your imagination!

22984.name: Vis Bellica
boardgameexpansion: Vis Bellica Army Lists Book 1: Chariots to 1st BC
22984.description:
From the publisher's website

Rules for Wargaming the Ancient Period

Figures based as chunky elements that correctly represent both ground scale and historical (as far as is known) units. Easy to move round the table and look good.

An average game consists of about 120 figures a side, and takes about 2½-3 hours of play to resolve.

A combat system that doesn’t involve complicated book-keeping or rolling more than two or three dice at a time.

A command structure where figures are grouped as regular ‘brigades’ or irregular ‘contingents’ that report to officers that report to more senior officers.

A command system where officers could, on a parade ground, successfully issue a limited set of orders to the figures under their command, but this ability breaks down rapidly as the 'fog of war' descends during a battle.

Hidden movement possible without the need for a referee.

Army lists that emphasize the common soldier as opposed to being a collection of special units grouped together

22985.description:
From the box: "Train your horse and win! Have you ever wanted to train your own horse? Now you can with the game Gallop Home! Travel around the board in this exciting, fun filled, educational game that will take your imagination into the horse world."

Each player chooses one of four horses, each having a corresponding game pad and a plastic, molded horse-head movement token. The game pad lists the training goals of each horse type; for example, the Arabian's most important training is pleasure, then, in sequence, halter, endurance, dressage, reining, driving, racing, trick riding, jumping, and barrels. Other horses emphasize different training schedules.
Players roll and move around the board, attempting to participate in the training most important to their horses. They also gather bonuses for proper care of their horses; for example, a stop at the vet scores points. The winner isn't necessarily the one to get to the end of the game board first, but to have accumulated the most points for training and care.
22985.name: Gallop Home

boardgamehonor: 2009 Kinderspielexperten "5-to-9-year-olds" Nominee
22987.description:
From the box:

Help this musical, talking turtle get out of the pond! Listen and Topsy Turtle will tell you what color block to place under his toes. Higher! Higher! Be the first player to use up all your blocks and you win. Be careful! If he topples, you get all the blocks back.

From the instructions:

Electronic Talking Topsy Turtle
24 Color Blocks
4 Turtle Legs
Pond Gameboard

Requires 4 x 1.5 volt AA batteries (not included)
22987.name: Topsy Turtle

22989.name: Royale Mastermind
22989.description: Royale Mastermind is a variant of Mastermind where two players solve 8 patterns, alternating between being the knower and the guesser. Shapes and colors are guessed independently on each side of the board. The total number of guesses each player requires to solve the color/shape pattern is tallied, the winner being the one to take the fewest guesses. The patterns consist of three elements, each having one of five shapes and one of five colors. A deck of 25 cards is used to establish the pattern, and after each card is used in a puzzle, it is not used again. The corresponding shape/color is also covered on a grid in the center of the board so the players can use this information in future rounds.

22990.description:
Les Aigles is a French Napoleonic miniature game set at the battalion level.

The rules are pretty standard for a Napoleonic miniature game of the era: semi-simultaneous game sequence, written orders, lots of tactical factors to take into account.

The game was published in two version, a boxed set with scenery elements to cut and build, as well as the standalone rulebook.

The rulebook featured both English and French rules on the same page, as was the case for other Jeux Descartes wargames like Guet-Apens (the translation was made by Hector A. Cornejo).

Expanded by

Les Aigles: supplément numéro 1
22990.name: Les Aigles

22991.name: Mona Lisa Mysteries
22991.description:
(from the web site)

Do You Have Da Vinci's Masterpiece? Based on the real events from 1911 when the Mona Lisa was stolen from the Louvre. Players act as wealthy art collectors who bid on the services of art "experts" to rate their copy of the Mona Lisa. Through careful strategy and market manipulation, the player with the highest valued Mona Lisa at the end of the game has the "real" Mona Lisa and wins the game.

Ages: Teen to adult
Players: 3 to 5
Contents: 5 Mona Lisa player painting boards, 44 expert cards, 56 bid cards, 60 gems, gem bag, value board, card tray and rules.

22992.name: Beat the Count
22992.description:
(from the web site)

Knock out your opponent and be the first to play ll of your cards successfully. Go ahead, "Beat The Count!"

Ages: 8 and up
Players: 3 to 8 players
Contents: 112 number and action cards and instructions

22993.name: Across Words
22993.description: The Electronic Talking Word Race Game! A rousing, high-fiving, laugh provoking, quick-thinking, adrenaline rush of a game! Players race to make the word that solves the clue. The talking "emcee" sets a lively pace from start to finish.

22994.name: Sackers
22994.description:
From the Publisher's web site:

Addictive game combining horseshoes and shuffleboard. Great for the beach, picnics, tailgate parties or even your own backyard.

Aim for year-round fun with our indoor/outdoor action game. Earn points when beanbags go through the hole or remain on the board at the end of your turn. But watch out… your opponents’ beanbags may knock yours off the board! Sackers combines the fun of horseshoes and shuffleboard in a game that’s safe, portable and addictively fun!

For 2 Players or Teams

No. 8000
Ages 8 & Up

22996.description:
Another in the Patch Products' series of "Big Deal" card games...

From the Publisher's web site:

Slap the Dragon! Slap him fast! Slap again when the pictures match! Simply put, those are all the rules in this adorable picture identifying and matching game for the little ones! No reading required.

Instructions in English and Spanish.

For 2 Players

No. 6627
Ages 4 and up
boardgameversion: Patch Products Big Deal Dinky Decks edition
22996.name: Slap Dragon

22997.name: Mad Scientist University Course Packet: Anthropology
22997.description:
Course Packs add 50 new cards from a specific discipline to the Mad Scientist University core game.

From the publisher:

ANTHROPOLOGY: The excavation has taken months, but it's been worth it. Brushing away the ancient dust, you find an excellent collection of stone-age pottery shards with terrible lizards carved in them. They all laughed in school, but you always knew you'd find the missing link between cavemen and dinosaurs!

22998.name: Venturers in Argent
22998.description:
Taken from the games website:
Venturers in Argent is a fantasy boardgame set in the World of Argent. It is a cooperative game in which as many as five players can participate, or as few as one (thus it is suitable for solitaire play). The players take on the parts of venturers, who set out to find treasure on a dangerous enterprise called a venture. The game can be played as a single venture in one session, or as a campaign of several ventures, with the power and abilities of the venturers increasing as they prepare for their final objective: the stronghold of the Silent Mountain … and the One Who Waits.

22999.name: 25 Words or Less: People, Places and Things Edition
22999.description:
(from the web site)

The all-new edition of the award-winning 25 Words or Less. You've got 1 minute and 25 words (or less!) of clues to get your teammates to shout out the five words on the card. Great party fun for groups of all sizes.

Ages: Teen to adult
Players: 4 or more players
Contents: Deck of 288 cards, countdown board, 1 minute sand timer, and instructions.

22501.name: See Sek
boardgamefamily: Card Games: Draw and Discard Games
22501.description:
This entry serves to represent the various games (mainly rummy games) that may be played with the See Sek deck of cards.

See Sek (also translated as Soo Sik; in HanYu PinYin it is Si Se) literally means four colors in Hokkien. This derives from the four colors (red, white, green, yellow) that form the suits of this deck of traditional Chinese playing cards. In English, these are sometimes described as Chess cards because they depict the Chinese characters from Chinese chess (XiangQi). As with most Chinese traditional playing cards, the cards are much longer than they are wide. However, there are regional variants with shorter cards.

Note that See Sek is different from Chess cards that only come in two colors and which are used for a different game.

A full deck consists of 112 cards: 28 cards in each of 4 suits (the colors). Each suit has the Chinese characters for the seven types of XiangQi pieces, repeated four times.

They are often used to play Rummy-type games and the melds may be three or four of exactly the same kind, three or four of a kind but in all different colors, single-card melds (the General or Ong), and three-card melds in 'sequence' and in the same color. There are two 'sequences': Ong, Soo and Chiau (Jiang, Shi, Xiang); and Koo, Beh, Pow (Ju, Ma, Pao).

In Singapore and Malaysia, these card games are often played by Hokkiens and Teochews.

22502.name: Belankai
22502.description:
Alternative names for this gambling game are Belankas or Belankai, though I more often hear it described as the latter. Belankas is the Malay name for the King Crab, one of the pictures featured in the game.

The game consists of a four-sided tee-totum. Modern Belankai spinners are made from a thin wooden dowel that runs through a cuboid piece of plastic with the pictures engraved on four sides. The pictures are a king crab, a flower/star/coin (hard to tell - the pictures are all stylized), a fish and a prawn (c.f. Hoo Hey How).

A staking board is drawn on any large piece of paper (or the ground) showing the four symbols. Players stake on the pictures and the banker (who will claim the stakes or pay winnings) spins the tee-totum in wide dish and covers it with a bowl. When the tee-totum comes to rest, it is revealed and players are payed according to whichever picture has come to rest on top.

Dobree describes that a plate of rice is often to be found where this game is played - it is used to hold the dish where the tee-totum is spun and serves to steady the dish and deaden the sound of the top when it is spinning.

22503.name: Hoo Hey How
22503.description:
Hoo Hey How is a Chinese dice game with similarities to Crown and Anchor dice. This gambling game consists of three dice with six different pictures on their sides and a paper board marked with the same six pictures for stakes to be placed on them. This board could be self-drawn but you can get printed boards together with the dice nowadays.

The name, Hoo Hey How, is derived from the Hokkien names of three of the things that usually appear on the dice = a fish (Hoo), a prawn (Hey) and a king crab (How). However, modern dice tend to show ordinary crabs.

Dobree, in the 1950s, described the objects commonly depicted on the dice: a fish, a prawn, a king crab, a flower, a butterfly, a beautiful lady. But he also noted that other pictures could also appear: a cat, a mouse, a cock, a centipede, a tiger, an elephant, a gourd, three coins (Chinese cash).

Today, the dice tend to show more standard pictures and the selection of pictures is standardized for the region where they originate too. For example, the dice in Malaysia and Singapore (and I assume Hong Kong, where many of them are made) depict a fish, a prawn, a crab, a Chinese coin, a gourd and a cockerel. Thai Hoo Hey How dice (called Nam Tou Bu Bak [please excuse my bad transliteration]) have a tiger instead of a coin, as do dice from the Malaysian state of Sabah, but the Sabah dice show the head of the tiger rather than the whole animal. In Vietnam, they are called Bau Cua Ca Cop and often played at the new year: the distinguishing feature is a stag instead of a coin. Another feature is that the dice may be made of cardboard.

Many variants are possible, some that do not even feature the Hoo, Hey or How, so I don't know what they would be called. From Penang in Malaysia, I have dice that feature an elephant, a rabbit, a butterfly, a snake, a centipede and a flower. In Singapore, some older dice I have feature mahjong dragons together with symbols of political parties from the 1950s.

To play, one player takes the role of banker and the others are punters. Players stake money on the betting board and the dice are cast (either under cover or into a porcelain bowl). Punters are paid an equivalent amount that they staked, the number of times their picture appears on the dice (e.g. if someone bet on the fish and it appears twice, the punter gets back twice their stake).

This game is similar to The Game of Crown and Anchor.

22504.name: Zhuang Yuan Chou
22504.description:
Zhuang Yuan Chou (Chong Yuen Chow in Cantonese) is a gambling game using dice and tallies, first mentioned in Chinese texts in the late 18th century, but still played today.

'Zhuang Yuan' is the title given to the scholar who achieved the highest distinction in the imperial examinations that determined entry into the Chinese bureaucracy.

The game consists of six dice and sixty-three tallies bearing titles of ranks of achievement in the examinations and the number of points they are worth. There is only one each of the top 3 positions, of which the highest value (32 points) and the largest tally is the Zhuan Yuan.
The lower the position, the thinner/shorter the tallies and the fewer points each is worth. At the lowest rank, Xiu Cai, there are 32 tallies worth 1 point each. As with many Chinese dice games, a porcelain bowl is often used to hold and roll the dice.

To play, punters agree on a value per point (Dobree mentions 1 cent, 10 cents or 50 cents). Each player takes turns rolling all six dice. According to the roll, the player is allowed to claim tallies of equivalent worth from the center of the table where they are initially placed. Certain rolls allow one to claim tallies from other players if those tallies were previously claimed. The game is played until all tallies have been claimed.

The best roll is six of a kind, allowing the player to claim all the tallies, whether they are in the pool or with other players. Five of a kind allows the player to claim the Zhuan Yuan tally wherever it is. Red fours (on Chinese dice, the one and four spots are red) are also good to roll - four of them will also get you the Zhuan Yuan tally. Dobree and Culin have both described the game including the values of the rolls.

In the past, tallies were made of bone and hand-engraved. Modern sets have brightly colored plastic tallies and can be found for sale in Mahjong shops in Singapore (and likely elsewhere).

22505.name: The Richest Christian
22505.description:
Learn what the Bible says about money.

Players spin and move their pieces. Each space is a positive or negative behavior and an associated Bible verse. Good behaviors are blessed with money, foolish behaviors pay penalties. At the beginning of their turn before they move, a player may choose to draw an "Opportunity" card. This is an opportunity to bless someone else, and involves giving away a certain amount of money to someone in need. In return, the player will earn "Treasures in Heaven". If a player cannot afford to pay the amount on the Opportunity card, they must pay a smaller fee for not wisely managing their finances. The first player to collect a set amount of Treasures (different based on the number of players) is the winner.

Bonus cash awards go to those who can quote the verses from memory, have read the Bible recently and those who learned something from a Bible teacher recently.

22506.name: Zambeln
22506.description:
Zambeln is a game supposedly played by teddy bears and other living toys. It is an extra to the Plüsch, Power and Plunder (PP&P) Role-Playing-Game in which toy pets come to life, and comes with the scenario "Plüsch, Drugs & Rock'n Roll."
Effectively, it is much like Uno, where every player plays a card per turn, which has to match the card played before; with some special card effects added, and two discard piles. First player to lose all his cards wins.

22507.description:
Thora's Vengeance is the fifth Small Expansion Set (wave 5) in the HeroScape series.

There are 4 boosters:

Ninjas & Samurai
Soulborgs
Warriors & Soulborgs
Gladiators & Agents




Each pack contains 6-7 new figures, army unit cards and some terrain pieces, but no glyphs.
22507.name: Heroscape Expansion Set: Thora's Vengeance
boardgameexpansion: Heroscape Master Set: Rise of the Valkyrie
Heroscape Master Set: Swarm of the Marro

22508.name: Burger Party
22508.description: Players are employees in a hamburger restaurant. They will have to take an order from one of the tables, put up the parts of the ordered meal and take it to the customer. The fastest waiter wins.

22509.description:
Four Battles of Army Group South consists of four completely separate regimental/divisional level games, each with its own 17" x 22" five-color map, unit counters and rules.

All four games use a set of Standard Rules derived from Panzergruppe Guderian as the basic core game rules. Each game then, has it's own set of Exclusive rules.

Kiev: The Battle of Encirclement, 1941, is a simulation of the German Blitzkrieg campaign from 29 August to 26 September 1941. It ended with the largest encirclement in history: 665,000 Soviets were destroyed; 3718 guns and 884 armored fighting vehicles captured; and the remains of the great Soviet prewar army of April 1941 was finished as a fighting force.
2 days per turn, 5 miles / 8 kilometers per hex.

Rostov: The First Soviet Counter-Attack, 1941, depicts the German drive across the Donets Basin in the fall of 1941. Army Group South, accompanied by various Axis-Allied Armies, attempted to seize the valuable communications junction at Rostov and establish bridgeheads across the Donets and lower Don rivers. In the fighting around Rostov, the Germans suffered their first strategic setback in their campaign against Russia, as the Soviet Army drove the German mechanized spearhead from this vital area.
2 days per turn, 10.5 miles / 17 kilometers per hex.

Operation Star: The Soviet Winter Offensive, 1943, the Soviet offensive towards Kharkov and Dnepr in February 1943 and the German counterattack that followed. Strong Soviet forces attempted to take Kharkov and sweep to the south and west, cutting off all of Army Group Don. Von Manstein formulated a daring counter-operation that called for the aggressive use of all available Panzer reserves.
5 days per turn, 6.5 miles / 10.5 kilometers per hex.

Korsun: The German Pocket on the Dniepr, 1944, depicts the battle of the encirclement - known to the Soviets as the Korsun Pocket and to the Germans as the Cherkassy Pocket - fought in late January and early February 1944, the largest German pocket since Stalingrad, only half the trapped German soldiers escape.
2 days per turn, 4.6 miles / 7.5 kilometers per hex.

Last in the series of SPI Quads.

Game Inventory:
Four 17 x 22" five-color mapsheets
Two dual-side printed countersheets (800 1/2" counters)
Two 8-page Army Group South Standard Rules rulebooks
Two 4-page Army Group South Charts & Tables booklets
Four 4-page game specific rulebooks
One 8-page AGS Historical Background booklet
One 6-sided die

Solitaire Playability: High
Complexity Level: Medium
Players: 2 or more
Playing Time: 3 - 4 hours
22509.name: Four Battles of Army Group South

22510.name: Wings of War: Miniatures
boardgameaccessory: Wings of War: Watch Your Back!
22510.description:
